Posts.Title: Resources to help painful hematoma 9 mos after sterotactic biopsy

Posts.Content:
My biopsy was done in November 2013.
They did a mammo immediately after. Three of them if I recall correctly, so they could get all planes.
Was a titanium marker placed? I've got one implanted so that my follow-up mammos can show specifically where to focus.
I understand how frustrating it can feel when you hear of others who just bounced right back and didn't have any problems,....it's natural to start making comparisons.
But hold steadfast to what our doctors tell us with regards to how everyone heals differently.
I've had procedures where I was told it would be painful afterwards and nadda, zip, zilch, I was fine. Other times, I was told things will be fine, and I was in enough pain to require additional rx medication (including topical rx lidocaine, which they told me was "unusual," that generally people simply don't need that level of pain management, blah-blah-blah).
Well, yeah,...good for them. Point is that "I do!" And that's what matters.
Some of the nurses were a tad dismissive of my discomfort/pain, and even though the doctor told me my pain was highly unusual, he still had my back! We do not all fall neatly into little columns and categories....
M.

Posts.Content:
I'd strongly encourage you to NOT do what you just wrote re: the abx.
If you are going to take them, take the entire rx exactly as prescribed by your doctor. Not finishing abx because we 'feel better' is one of the biggest contributing factors to developing super bugs. Dangerous plan!
Either take them as directed, or discuss with your doctor about
 making the confirmation that there IS indeed an infection going.
As for the soreness, gotta say, mine have come and go in terms of being painful. Sometimes they are, sometimes they are not, sometimes the same one will have moments of being a big ole pain, and then settle down and just be a lump.
But please, please, do NOT just take a few of those abx pills and then abruptly stop. Please discuss this with your doctor waaaaay in advance!!

Posts.Title: Resources to help painful hematoma 9 mos after sterotactic biopsy

Posts.Content:
Is the red spot warm to the touch? Are you running a temp? Did your doc run blood work to check your WBC before rx'ing you an antibiotic?
My only concern with abx is that, in my opinion, some docs rx them out like candy w/o knowing if they're really needed, ..... ergo, we now have super-bugs that our regular run of the mill abx don't work on anymore, and they're having to create more and more powerful strains.
As for the aspiration,...again, just my personal chime in,....it's over before you know it. I've always had lumpy breasts and after a while, you just get used to your new normal.
Please do not get concerned if after he aspirates it, the lump returns. A cyst is a solid sack, a membrane, and it's attached. The fluid inside that sack gets pierced and the fluid is retrieved through aspiration. But unless the sack is detached and remove, that cyst, all cysts wherever they are (same goes for things like cystic acne, or body cysts), our bodies just fill that cavity back up again over time. So please don't worry yourself if that happens, okay?

My situation is different in terms of we do not share the same dx, however, between my spine surgeries and BC, I haven't worn a bra either, and I've only been able to start wearing pants (loose) since around September because.....yep, having anything touching my skin or wrapping around my whole body is unbelievably painful!
I'm on a compound cream that sounds like the same thing. I didn't think it was doing much until my insurance stopped filling it for 3 months and I realized,.....yep, it actually does make a difference!
If you're experiencing nerve pain, you could ask your doctor about
 meds specifically *for* nerve pain. Narcotic pain meds have little effect on nerve pain. Other meds taken systemically, (such as Gabapentin, Lyrica, etc.) are designed specifically for neurological pain.
It's certainly worth mentioning to your doctor.
I'm a year and a half out from my back surgery and 6-7 months out from BC surgery, with my radiation which ended on 4/1.

The laetrile debacle has been discussed before, and it just gets dicey when people try to make connections between apricot seeds (which are not FDA approved for treating CA), which also cannot be monitored re: content (ie: active ingredient varies seed to seed, or nut to nut if you will).
I remember when this hit in the 90's sometime and there was this rush in sales. 
I do not want to infringe on anyone's right to choose their own form of treatment and therapy, and I will admit there are a lot of things in nature that can help, and I'll admit there are many treatments that may be slow to develop for acceptance in the USA....
That being said, we do need to at least keep in mind ethical treatment. I'm not trying to dismiss that, or any treatment, in particular, but I'd hate to see someone avoid appropriate medical care all together and eat an unknown quantity of a substance. Just urging caution when making correlations or claims....

Not much I can help in this regard, but I'm glad that you're getting this taken care of now rather than later.
I'd be asking the doctor specifically "what makes you think I have had those" done and ask for specifics. I'm guessing that given the diagnostics, the only thing left to do is to actually remove them and see what they are.
Did they do an ultrasound of the regions?
I've never had an implant of that variety so I'm genuinely unfamiliar if they can migrate or not. But since other devices can find their way to migrate, I suppose it's possible. It might be improbable, but possible. At least you're getting it checked out now.
Artificial things migrate in our bodies all the time as they're foreign material and our bodies aren't keen on having foreign objects in our body. Some bodies accept them more readily than others.
It could be something totally unrelated. Did they ultrasound the original area of that implant to see if it was still in its original place or if they could identify that it had moved?

Posts.Title: Crohn's patient on Remicade diagnoised with breast cancer

Posts.Content:
I had 28 session with 5 boosts as well.
The "mock" one includes x-ray set ups which you'll receive weekly to check on the alignment, the so-called tattoos are just the size of a dot and you don't really feel them. These and the x-rays and "mock" scan are done so they can take the measurements and know in advance where to project the rad.
You really do get used to it, and since you go 5 days a week, it just becomes routine.
My oncos have told me to refrain from having any breast surgery in the breast that had the partial mast. But see, I did something different than you....I had what was considered elective surgery to remove tissue from both breasts that was pre-cancerous and showed significant changes to the tissues via comparison. That is why I had a plastic surgeon brought in on my team.
HE told me they can do a fat graft if I wanted to try and equal my (now rather quite) asymmetrical breasts. What's left of them.
Truth is, I'm liking the small one and I'm seeing him to discuss having the "larger" one (which is still pretty darn small, think an orange in a sock) reduced. My scars are beautiful, they can hardly be seen unless you look super close.
Yes, the rad made that one breast more dense but from my perspective, it just got a little firmer so it isn't as "floppy." It isn't hard. I still have quite the evidence of the rad burns on my super sensitive skin, so we're waiting.
But I like my smaller ta-tas, and I'm looking forward to having the left one reduced to match.
Oh, btw, after all this, my doc has also scheduled a colonoscopy. Oh yay, golly, can't wait for that, yep, that's going to be fun, oh me oh my,.....(sigh)
But my pap came back normal, so that's good. Time to weed things out. Lots of CA in my now deceased Father, but none anywhere else. 
Time to get "the works" checked out. Heck, we made it this far, right!!
M.

Posts.Title: Overian Cancer scare or is it IBS im so lost !!! please help

Posts.Content:
Periods and problems with bowels can all be interrupted with stress,....to say the least. When we're stressed, our eating patterns change, our hormones get affected, constipation can contribute to back pain, an unbalanced diet can even fiddle with our menstrual cycles, -- especially if you're under-eating, malnourished, or athletic with low body fat.
Before jumping the gun into thinking this may be any type of cancer, it sounds like you've been thoroughly checked out by your physicians. Symptoms too numerous to mention can "cross over." Some symptoms of IBS are the same as if you are dehydrated or ate too much cheese.
So before getting worked up, take a deep breath, trust your doctors....and trust that anxiety has a rainbow of symptoms and styles in which it affects our lives!
If you do not feel safe, consult another physician if that will help ease your mind.
M.

Posts.Title: bra recommendations

Posts.Content:
I have my own MT but she is not certified in lymphedema/lymphatic flushing, etc. At the cancer center, they permit each patient two free 30 minute complimentary massage sessions with a therapist specifically trained in working with BC patients (or any CA patients where lymph nodes have been removed).
My PT's working on my right shoulder (same side as BC, of course) and doing soft tissue work on my neck and shoulder, and my MT has done full body massages....once she did work on my right arm (but she knew how to flush), and then yesterday I told her for now I was told nothing on the right arm, not yet.
I know that some places, like chiro offices and naturopathic offices will make arrangements to bill under their heading. Mine will not, nor would either of us want them to.....what goes around comes around, and I am leery and questionable about
 practices that do any type of insurance billing in what seems like less than up front ways. MT is so darn expensive though....this is going to be a temporary luxury.
This confuses me because we cannot have BP taken, yet we can wear compressive sleeve garments? Yet we can have lymphatic drainage massage? These are mixed signals.
I see my rad onco next Wednesday (I saw his "fill in" today who I perceived wanted nothing more than to spend as little time with each patient as possible and dodging questions right and left, inching out the door). MY onco is way cooler, so I'll ask him next week. Since my MT is trying to work on my right shoulder, it does involve my pec muscle, deltoid, bicep, inner tricep, traps, scalenes,....all the muscles needing "digging into" to release the shoulder but I've got sort of mixed messages about
 do's and don'ts.
The cancer center allows 2 free 30-minute appointments with their MT, so I'm going to make those appts and pick up tips and pass them along.
Funny thing. Dana Farber offers massage (and Reiki) to all of their CA patients as part of their "Living With Cancer" wellness program. But I called my insurance, and for the first time since I've had my insurance (which I've had forever minus 6 months)....as long as I got a letter of medical necessity, they'd cover massage, and even acupuncture. (For reimbursement, not direct pay).
This year, it's a no go. They will not accept any claims from any CMT, even if they are deemed medically necessary. I'm instructed, we all are, to maintain pliability, flexibility and ROM of the arm/s affected by the BC and radiation....something I'm already struggling with.
But even though it's all over their papers, pamphlets and posters,.....it must be in my head. Right?
M.
...
"My time for tears will be at my Victory...not at the start of the War." ~~Vickie
Posts.Title: Massage with BC

Posts.Content:
I thought I'd mention something about
 the rocking.
I've done that (even before BC) and still do. My Husband has picked up on it along the years and rocks me when I'm feeling anxious or am in pain and scared.
For me, it goes back to being a little girl and having Daddy rock me....for some of us, rocking is just a natural way to comfort and soothe.
One time I was at my Mother in Law's and she saw me rocking back and forth. She knew it was because I was in pain and distress. She even commented that it was a good thing 
 knew what it meant, because it's possible someone else might not quite understand!
Perhaps hold your sister and rock 
 her? You might be surprised at you both will feel!

Posts.Title: Sister Starting Chemo on April 1st

Posts.Content:
The best route in determining what's going on isn't going to involve going straight into any one particular diagnostic, but rather, it's the combination that help determine the specifics of what's going on, the 
locations, if it's spread or has the potential to, how advanced it is...
These things require several "views" (or tests) so that your doctor can get complete pictures of what's going on. Skipping steps means something else could be missed.
There really is a method to their madness! We just have to learn to trust that....
M.

Posts.Title: 2 Mammograms and an ultrasound later...?

Posts.Content:
I'm still in quite a bit of pain. The surgeon didn't anticipate too much, but also told me I had a lot of tissue taken out. As I mentioned, 3 incisions: One in the left breast, and two in the right. Wow, did I lose a lot of volume!! Now I'm graced with bunches of divots and hollow pockets, and one very bruised (and now inverted) nipple.
I just started a new med today other than Tylenol. He gave me Vicodin, and so far, not much help, but I'm getting the most help from the ice packs.
I'm fine with achy and sore and I'm even fine with the bruises that are starting to show up. I can feel the "pockets" from the spaces created inside where the tissues were removed, and that one arm pit feels like it's been plucked with a pair of pliers!
I really do accept a degree of discomfort and ache, but wowza, this hurts a lot more than I expected it to. I understand time will heal and that this is temporary. But I noticed when I reached over with my left arm (the one without the sentinel node biopsies), it felt just a little bit like the pocket, which was trying to heal, was easily beginning to pull 
open.
So I'm doing my best to do nothing and let this fluid resorb into my body. I'm just so astonished that the meds they gave me aren't offering any relief!
M.
My time for tears will be at my Victory...not at the start of the War. ~~Vickie
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
I'm not sure if it's called a JOBE bra, or a JOB bra,....
But it's exactly what you described. There's a zipper in the front up the middle, and the shoulder straps Velcro close so they're adjustable. I just keep stuffing each side with "fluffy gauze" which has been collecting the blood and fluids.
They just called to ask if I can come in an hour early because we're supposed to get hit with (......wait for it.....) another sleet and ice storm this afternoon.
I 
 going to say that "nothing seems to be going my way," but that's really not the truth, because the cancer is out, and with hope, he has the Path report when I see him today. I would imagine tomorrow at the latest.
They've taken very good care of me, and they've stayed in touch with me, and I've been receiving calls from social workers and BC support groups (they have a little network going, and I think it might be nice to communicate with others, to learn more about
 this, and to be able to share,...beyond the book and binder they gave me). 
The Center has been really good at reaching out to me.
Quite sincerely, my only complaint is that even now, 6 days later, I'm still in considerable pain. Not "just an ache," and not "just pulling," but pain. I hope he sees this and is willing to prescribe something stronger, but to be honest, the impression I get is that I'm not holding out much hope.
As I mentioned, I don't think they understand how to prescribe pain medication for someone who's already taking CP meds (which, btw, strangely enough, aren't even touching this pain.....why would that be? I mean other than one is for CP and this is acute pain...Silly me still thought it would help, maybe a little). His RN asked if I could "just take more" of the pain med I had on hand. If he doesn't help me today, I will contact my prescribing physician, explain what's going on, and ask. Because this is nuts. I'm expecting him to tell me it "shouldn't be hurting" like this a week after surgery. Maybe not, but golly, it does.
I got that Texas sized bee sting thing! At first I didn't understand because the two injections (the lidocaine then the radioactive dye), did not hurt, and didn't leave a mark. Then voila, 2 days later,....there it was: Quite aptly put: My TX sized bee sting, like a welt just blooming on my breast).
Perdy.
M.
My time for tears will be at my Victory...not at the start of the War. ~~Vickie

Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
Well I just got home,....and I reiterated how much pain I am still in, (not "discomfort" or "aching"). He noted that while both breasts still show "moderate swelling," there is "obviously more swelling and bruising" on the right one (where the nodes were taken from).
No path report yet. I'm seeing him again in one week. He did comment on the amount of tissue that was removed being remarkable so we both knew going in, that the "after" would be dramatic.
As far as the pain goes, he did not prescribe anything, he told me there's really nothing more he could do, and all he could recommend at this point was ice, my regular pain meds, more ice, compression,......
He DID say that he will not make me wait until my f/u appointment next Monday to find out the path results, and that there's no reason I should be kept waiting for them, and that he will call me immediately when he gets them.
He told me that I do not have a fever (which I know, because I've been taking it), there are no signs of infection (such as warmth, redness, and there's only a tiny bit of drainage coming through onto the gauze pads in the bra, nothing remarkable), so as he saw it, everything looked very good, and he was quite pleased. (And with no sign of infection, I made the assumption, I'll admit it, that therefore I somehow "shouldn't" be in this much pain?)
I'll let you guys know when I hear from him with the path report, and I'll check in after I have my follow up in one week. In the meantime, keep the girls wrapped or compressed in this bra with gauze.
Other than having to just suck it up re: the pain, I came away from today's appointment feeling pleased, as he was pleased with the results. I'm assuming by next Monday, given the path report will be in by then too,....that 
 is when I'll have a better idea of what my future looks like with regards to radiation therapy, etc. 
(Now tomorrow I have to go get XRays of my spine because I fell and landed right where my fusions are,--of course,--is there any other way?...so here's hoping I don't get to add 
 to my extensively growing list of "things to do" in the Health Department here!)
M.
My time for tears will be at my Victory...not at the start of the War. ~~Vickie

Posts.Title: architectural distortion on mammogram

Posts.Content:
Oh, thank you so much Jane! I appreciate every bit of support I get.
I feel really fortunate that the PS was there to remove all that other precancerous tissue. I am very fortunate and blessed that our insurance company was willing to pay for this as well.
My surgeon feels that I am "probably in more pain" because this was more involved than a standard lumpectomy. (But evidently, not so sure that's "worthy" of stronger pain meds?)
I don't want to go through any of this ever again, if that was a choice that helped to increase my chances, that I'm happy about
 it. They removed so much tissue, I look like I have the profile of a 12 year old boy now.
And that's okay. As Hubby reminds me,..the most important thing is taking care of, and that is this cancer. I swear, I've married the most wonderful man in the world! (Heck, we've come a long way,..."working on each other"....and all for the better).
As for the fusions and decompressions, my concern is this: I fell backwards, my T12/L1 landing right against the door knob of one of the drawers in the kitchen island. Then as I slipped, I landed directly on my sacrum.
When I had my back surgery (a year ago) he told me my L5-S1 was very tenuous, and he contemplated fusing that area as well because it was so damaged, but he decided against it to help keep me as mobile as possible.
So when he asked me if I was having back pain,...or back and leg pain,...and I told him both,-- things got silent for a bit. Nothing has improved since that fall, but I'm realistic enough to know that so much "other stuff" has been going on, that I haven't been able to immerse myself into PT like I normally would, and I've gained weight from sitting around (and I'm at maximum density, so I can really feel these pounds).
The bruises were pretty gnarly looking, and as of today, they're mostly dissipated.
I just fell at the worst time, in such a bad way, hitting the areas of my fusions he told me were not as stable as he'd like, but fusing L1 through L5 was his best choice.
Too much stuff going on. Too many plates full. Having a hard time juggling.
M.

In my experience, when I've had something migrate (such as bone chips), scar tissue forms around whatever has migrated and thickens, creating a fibrous protective layer between that which has migrated, and the natural tissue.

If you still haven't heard anything, general rule in most doctor's offices is that they'd only phone/contact you if something suspicious turned up.
I know in my own doctor's office, they have multiple signs posted everywhere (including the bathroom!) stating to NOT phone the office for test results....
((sigh))
If the results are normal, it's typical that they'll send you something by traditional snail-mail with your results. If you haven't received that, I personally don't think it would be out of the question to schedule an appointment with your doc to review the results.

Posts.Title: Special Views after Mammogram

Posts.Content:
Mindy,
For more imaging do you mean an ultrasound or another mammogram?
Usually they'll do an ultrasound shortly after mammo results are in. I'm not sure what to suggest other than calling your doctor and mentioning that you'd really like to get in sooner, and be honest, that you're scared and anxious.
The word "mass" in and of itself can pertain to so many things, so I wouldn't let that in particular get stuck in your craw. A cluster of benign cysts is a mass. A fatty tumour is a mass.
It wouldn't hurt to at least try and get your doctor to understand how you feel and get an earlier appointment.

Posts.Title: Solid lump that started soft and larger

Posts.Content:
Before you panic and think the worse, it could always be a cyst, or group of cysts.
I have them since I was 14, and I am now 51.
Check with your GYN, and see if perhaps a mammogram could be performed, and/or even an ultrasound.
I've been down this road lots of times, so deep breath....If it's a cyst, they don't always have to remove them. They can aspirate them, and in many cases they leave them alone.
The mammo and/or ultrasound will give a clearer picture of what's going on and thus what action to be taken.
Congrats on being thorough enough to discover this now, this early on, and going to get it checked out!!

Posts.Title: Confused about my condition

Posts.Content:
Yes, my insurance will cover it. Yes, I've had tissue removed from both breasts. BC was only in the right one.
Resultant surgery has left breast sagging and flopping, while right breast, while it's still healing unbelievably slowly (still inflamed but onco gave me OK, all is well), the right one is on track.
Saw plastic surgeon yesterday to have left one reduced to match right one.
Spoke to Hubby and he's flat out against it. He does agree it's my body, and it's mine to do with as my conscience sees fit.
From his perspective, *I* need perspective, and be happy as-is w/o risking another surgery after all the surgeries I've been through. Especially for cosmetic reasons. The surgery WOULD involve a lollipop incision and that scares both of us.
If there's another alternative I don't know it.
He has valid points and I understand I'm lucky to have found the BC when I did, and given my long history of other problems and Sx's, I need to learn to be content with what God gave me.
Just need to talk I guess, vent, share, ask? I dunno.....
If the difference weren't so significant (to me at least, it's pretty darn obvious) I wouldn't be entertaining this idea.
Guys? What do you think?
M.

Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
I've been making some big mistakes with my diet that need to be rectified, and that starts this morning.
I don't always (not yet anyway, but I will!!) eat my foods in the correct order. It should always be protein first, and I've been slacking.
I found a protein powder that is UNSWEETENED (no sugar, sweeteners, artificial chemicals, sugar alcohols, nothing!!) and it's a low carb protein. I used it when I was lifting,...not sure why I forgot about
 it.
So now I have UNFLAVOURED protein powder, 24 grams of protein per scoop plus BCAA's. I'm going to mix that up with frozen fruit, water, a capful of vanilla extract as a carrier, flax seed powder, psyllium seed powder, and a tablespoon of flax seed oil....maybe a few ice cubes too. But this will help me get more protein into my diet, more nutrients, and hopefully help lower my cholesterol too. (My body does NOT like statins in the least, so I'd like to try diet and exercise first, especially with all this crappola going on!)
Not sure why I forgot it. Ohhhh, yeah. Maybe because my darling Husband, in his effort to make the house appear tidy, just puts stuff away I have on the counter (so I can see it and it reminds me to use it),...and stuffs whatever he finds in whatever cabinets are near-by. No wonder I can't find anything!
So there's my golden nugget of knowledge to carry forth: Protein FIRST before introducing other nutrients,...even with real food, that's super big important.
Now to implement my master plan!!
M.

Posts.Title: Can Doctor's tell by if a lump is a cyst from an examination?

Posts.Content:
I could tell you how many times I've had to do repeat tests, but I'd probably bore you! ;)
When they call you back, that in and of itself is not necessarily bad news. That's your doctor wanting to make sure and wanting to do a thorough exam. That's excellent, and you should be quite pleased!
"Masses" in the breast,.....ahh, well, you see that covers a whole wide range of things. Lipomas or fatty nodules, swollen ducts, cysts, calcifications,....etc., etc.
Oh toots, the list goes on.
Honest, until you have something to worry about
, take a step back, and let the doctors and techs do their work and you'll find out soon enough.
I've got puncture marks all over from biopsies,.....it's just part of life for some of us! You hang tight!
M.

Posts.Title: Found Lump On Routine Exam

Posts.Content:
Uhm, please remember I am not a doctor, okay? But I cannot imagine that kind of choice. The node biopsy will be the tell-all because that gives the doctor the information to know how aggressive and/or advanced this is, and also what potential there is for this cancer to spread.
I would ask the doc to send that sample out for what's called an OncoTypeDX which will give you a concrete number (it's based on 3 values) to determine what type of treatment is best.
So, no, I have never heard of a doctor scheduling a surgery without knowing in advance what he's doing.
Some people get prophylactic mastectomies. I had that done as well (partial) on the pre-cancerous tissue in the breast on the other side, in addition to having the cancer removed from my breast.
Please double check with your doc.
M.

Posts.Title: Weird questions asked at Mammogram

Posts.Content:
I wish I could help you out and offer not only information, but also subjective experience.
In my case, I got diagnosed in November 2013, had surgery December 2013, and over the last 2 weeks, I had my first meetings with my radiation oncologist, then my medical oncologist.
My radiation therapy should start in about
 3 weeks, and then the hormones.
My medical onco sent my tissue out for a test called OncoTypeDX. Of the three markers, there was one negative one which concerned her, and that's why she sent the tissue out, and that will tell me if I need chemo on top of all this.
Now, as I understand it (remember, I'm speculating, because I'm just stepping into those shoes as we speak). Part of the way the hormones work is to block or reduce estrogen. So that's the opposite of HRT which introduces estrogen to the body.
Women I know who went on HRT, and thereby increasing their estrogen levels, one (of the many) side effects was that they noticed their skin improving greatly.
So, I'm guessing that in our case, when we're put on meds to lower estrogen even further, one possibility is that it has the opposite effect on our skin, compared to HRT, and unfortunately that may include losing elasticity in our skin.
Remember, not only am I not a doctor, but I'm several steps behind you with regards to hormone therapy and the side effects.
Did you mention your concerns to your medical oncologist? Did they discuss any of this with you before you had your hormone therapy? Your onco will have much more information on what's going on.
Please post back and let us know how you make out!
M.

Posts.Title: Lump in lymph node in breast

Posts.Content:
Hello there IAS,
And welcome aboard the BC train!
I read your previous two comments written on a different thread, and would like to pop in with my $ 0.02.
Just wanted to mention that "calcifications" do not always go hand-in-hand with BC, and in-and-of themselves are not always scare-flags.
Since I was 14, I always had lumpy breasts (fibrocystic breast disease) and around the corner every few years, I'd find out that I had calcification clusters, in both breasts, along with clusters of fibrotic tissue and cysts. These formations maintained, and some changed, for many years.
I am now 51.
When they put you on your tummy to do these tests, your breasts are,....exposed to hang freely (I can't think of any more delicate way to phrase that, but I know you now get the picture). So it isn't the same as if you're lying prone on a firm surface, like your bed or beach sand.
If you feel you'll be anxious, always discuss with your doctor the possibility of being prescribed something for anxiety for that day, that you can take to help quell your nerves a bit and relax you. I do not 
 but am not positive, that they would offer any type of injectable sedative. (They didn't for me, anyway).
As some of us mentioned, in reality, it isn't as bad of an experience as our imaginations would lead us to believe! I was quite comfortable. They go out of their way to make sure you're propped up in such a way to feel supported. They realize this is an awkward position to be in, and you'll find they really do go out of their way to help you feel as de-stressed as possible! :)
M.

Posts.Title: Breast cancer back?

Posts.Content:
Ahh, okay, I getchya.
I've had fibrocystic breasts since I was 14 years old. It's sooooo common for these cysts to muck up the standard diagnostic tools that we have to go back for further exams.
You're right. Cysts in general turn out to be more of a pain and inconvenience. There's a good chance your doc just wants to follow up and make sure. Rather than assume. That's a very good thing!!
My guess is if the aspirated fluid/tissue pulled up malignant cells you'd be in there so fast your head would spin. That you're schedule for something generally considered a bit more routine and a follow-up *may* be why your doctor doesn't feel this is an emergency.
You can always ask to have the test sooner, express your anxiety and concern, ask to be put on a call list, etc.
about
 10-15 years ago I felt a hard lump in my left breast the size of a quarter that did not feel like one of my regular cysts, and it was at the 4:00 position, not where I usually have my clusters of cycsts,.....and I called Brigham & Women's ....pretty much the magical pioneer caring institute for breast health in my area, explained the situation, and the soonest they could get me in just for an exam was several months later.
I understand the anxiety, I really do. (BTW: That quarter sized lump turned out to be nothing) But that didn't detract from the sheer panic of waiting and not knowing.

Posts.Title: Hair regrowth after Taxotere ?

Posts.Content:
Now that you mention it, I do recall seeing your name over on the AP forum. As you've noticed, it's a pretty busy place.
I know what you mean about
 how all these visits and referrals are burning a hole in your pocket. I've found starting in January of this year, I'm jumping through more fiery hoops of red-tape and denials than I've ever had to (and we have excellent insurance), I'm receiving denials on meds they filled just a month ago,...and this is just the beginning I fear.
Why do you feel like they are not listening to you? Because they refer you to another doctor? Are they referring you to specialists who may have more experience in dealing with what your Dx's indicate?
I understand not getting answers, and I want to ask you: Do you ask questions? Sometimes we expect, (I know my history has been this way and I am in the process of learning to change that),...if we state what our problems/complaints/issues are,....that should be sufficient for the doctor to understand we're concerned and provide feedback on what we're commenting on.
For various reasons, it often takes direct and specific questions, many times they have to be repeated over and over, even within the same visit, to get answers. Again, something I'm learning now, standing up for myself when I feel they're dodging me.
Asking specific questions, and not leaving or being satisfied until you get specific answers, goes a long way. Ask particulars, like what they're ruling out, what they're looking for, what does your Dx mean and how does that translate to your goals of having a family,....why are they referring you to someone else, what do they anticipate these new doctors will detect that they, themselves, aren't able to....
All too often they are hard questions to ask, but we must persevere. And heads up, they'll try to make you feel uncomfortable for having the gall to dare ask about
 your very own health (<-- read sarcasm!)....but keep at it. It takes practice, it involves working through lots of nervousness and fear of rejection and judgment, but....don't despair, just keep plugging along. 
This is your body, and by golly, you have every right to have all your questions answered to your satisfaction. Get a copy of your medical records (COMPLETE) and read them,...see if they are "accidentally" omitting information, or see if they're choosing their words a little too carefully, if you know what I mean, when relaying information to you.
We say it all the time, we mean it all the time, and yet it remains one of the most challenging things we must do: But we simply must be our own best advocate!
M.

Posts.Title: Please help. Found lump. Am terrified!!!

Posts.Content:
Roxy,
First of all, "Good for you!" -- for making that appointment now! I know how tough a decision that is to make, just making that phone call. I'm sure the anxiety gets compounded because things are uncertain with your insurance at the moment.
Now, from what you've written, it sounds like that your "starting point" will be a standard mammogram. That's usually the first step, the basic diagnostic tool that helps to give an overall picture of what's going on.
I've had fibrocystic breasts since I first started my period, so it was not uncommon throughout the years for my doctors to have me repeat mammograms or get ultrasounds. So for now, you get to tuck this away into a little box for later because you have effectively handled it.
You felt something wrong, you monitored it, you asked for help and suggestions and input, and you followed up by calling your doc to schedule an appointment for as close to "immediate" as anyone could hope for! Gosh, if you think about
 it, it's not that far away. It's less than 4 weeks, so that's great!
Now, just don't over-think things because you've done a great job of taking care of matters. It's a done deal!
Good for you!

Posts.Title: Staph infection from Biopsy

Posts.Content:
A few things stick out to me when I read your post.
You have had two ultrasounds, and they are both negative, correct? How far apart were the tests performed? Trust me, your physicians are extremely more qualified than Dr. Google,--plus, they examine you in person, view and conduct your personal tests directly, and aren't making generalizations and grasping at far-fetched random straws, like that "family cousin" we don't invite to gatherings: Dr. Google. He's always starting some sort of ruckus. Best to let him be.
If you've had two separate ultrasounds, why do you think they are lying to you about
 the results? There are no benefits in doing so.
What makes you think they are ignoring your "signs?" Did you tell them "your signs?" They heard you? Did it occur to you they
 in fact listen, and that's why they did the ultrasounds? 
 of them?
PCOS is very common, so trying to find some secret, magic "cure" will only result in frustration. Are you trying to get pregnant and having a hard time conceiving, and this is why you're worried?
You mention your weight, so have you had your blood sugar tested for insulin resistance, or have you had a glucose tolerance test? Has insulin resistance and/or diabetes been ruled out? (Or did Dr. Google scare with you with horror stories? He's quite fond of doing that, and every now and again, we collectively need to give him a good swift kick in the pants!)
You did "research?" What kind, where, how, and from whom?
I'm curious why you're latching onto IBS and OC as the only 2 possibilities.... Do you know just how many different conditions can cause the same or similar symptoms? Did you know that,....without a label of some long-named disease,....that by simply losing weight, you can experience improvements in your symptoms?
Oh my dear, so many of us have been scared witless by too much "research" on the web. Give it a break, take care of yourself, trust your physicians,.....of course ask questions, get answers, and above all, implement the advice given you.
Post here often because we're here at all sorts of crazy hours,....and we do understand the confusion and frustration!
M.

Something happened, something IS happening along the way.....and I feel like we're being left behind.

Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
You're doing a great job! Give yourself a lot of credit.
Also, please rest assured that the tests they are asking for, and the order in which they are asking for them, is perfectly normal. You are doing fine, you really are!
I know this can feel scary. It's the unknown.
Many women have cystic breasts, and they can occur (like in my case, they started when I got my period and just got lumpier and moved around ever since then). It is not uncommon.
Sometimes if they can identify a particularly hard or painful cyst, they'll aspirate it, or drain the fluid out of it. This doesn't hurt, and afterwards, things feel better because the painful lump isn't there anymore.
Cysts can refill with fluid, which may or may not need to be drained again, but you'll know what to expect
The MRI is fun (sarcasm) because you lay on your tummy and your breasts hang down so the machine can capture images. But really, it's not that bad. A little noisy but it doesn't take all that long, and it provides a lot more information than the mammogram and ultrasound.
You're doing the right things, so be proud of your accomplishments!

The one "food item" that everyone I have seen about
 this since I had that first mammogram when I was diagnosed,...is caffeine. With all the questionnaires I had to fill out before seeing each doctor, before each diagnostic test, with each health professional I've seen (including my PMC), while they ask about
 things like smoking and drinking,....the only "food product" that gets inquired about
 is caffeine consumption.
I can remember back in the 1980's when I got my first mammogram,...when I first found out how congested my breast tissues were, being told I have fibrocystic breast disease (nothing to worry about
, as they explained at the time, just lumpy breasts, and in my case, it became quite extensive and very painful)...we also monitored the calcifications in addition to the growing number of cysts and their rate of growth and 
locations,...
As the years progressed, and as the changes were being noted, that was the first time (that I recall) being instructed to reduce my caffeine consumption,--merely citing that "excessive caffeine intake can exacerbate my breast disease."
I never really questioned it beyond that, but didn't forget it.
It was also brought up when I saw my PMD Friday, and (as I'm still feeling in a whirlwind) it never occurred to me to ask what the correlation was.
Best I can tell, other than that mystery, I think the best any of us can do is common-sense eating as healthy and balanced as possible. And for me, it's been recommended that in addition to getting protein in my diet, to supplement with protein shakes. (Which I make from scratch using unflavoured, unsweetened protein, frozen fruit, flax oil, psyllium husk powder, and flax seeds).
You make a good point. Beyond genetics, it isn't like we can link our getting BC to something we did or ate, so it does make sense, we cannot prevent a recurrence along those same lines. Thank you again for replying. I am still learning.

One step at a time.
Remember what breast tissue is made of. Throughout out entire lives, the shape, density, consistency, appearance,....all of that will change many times.
Check with your doctor and see what he has to say, and as I mentioned, post back and let us know how you make out.
In my own personal experience, if I got a bra to fit one cup, inevitably the other one wouldn't. C'est la vie.
So now I wear sports bras and you can't even tell.
But let your doctor know in advance of your concern and see if it's something he feels he needs to take a closer look at.
M.

Posts.Title: Asymmetry, now worried

Posts.Content:
Our minds are powerful, and it is quite possible that because you're feeling nervous, you're more aware of various sensations in your body.
You're just being hyper-vigilant and that's perfectly normal. Any time we're called in for some type of diagnostic testing, I think most of us get butterflies and focus excessively on whatever area is being scanned.
The ultrasound will show the doctor a clearer picture of what's going on. I've been getting mammograms since I was in my 20's (I am 50 now), and it was not uncommon for me to get called back for ultrasounds because I developed very cystic breasts since I hit puberty.
Take a bunch of deep breaths, a nice hot cup of tea, and post back when you've had the test done and let us know how things go, okay?
M.

Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
Another cause of "thickening" can be,....hormones, puberty, having uneven breast sizes (which pretty much counts most of us here,...don't think I know of a single person who is symmetrical).
When I started my period, I developed cystic breasts. It's very common (so please avoid going to Dr. Google to check on every little symptom....if you type in enough stuff they'll tell you that changes in breast density may cause ingrown toenails....). (My point is,....in my opinion, that place scares more people than it helps).
I'm not a doctor, I'm not a medical professional, and nothing you read here should ever take the place of the advice of your real doctor. So, that's first, right out of the gate.
I've had dense, or "lumpy breasts" for over 30 years. It's much more common that you may realize. Sure, hormones play all kinds of roles in our development,----breasts, and otherwise.
Let me share something with you: I grew up around horses since I was a kid, and at one point, through my own fault, nothing to do with my horse, I got kicked in the chest. Yes, when you injure an area that is so dense, filled with glands, and nodes, and ducts, and fat, and fibrous tissue,....well heck yeah, you better believe you can bruise the area. (Our lady bits are tender, after all).
My doc just kept an eye on me, but it never stopped me from caring for my horses (that was my life, my horses!!)....
It doesn't take something that drastic to get a bruise or trauma to the tissue, but my point is, hey, it happens. Learn to trust your doctor. Learn to stay away from trying to read between the misleading lines of Google, and go out and live your life. Stay in touch with your doctor (who will monitor any changes and keep a good eye on you)....
That's 
 job, you know....looking after you. So,...let them do their job without trying to second to guess them, especially with something as completely unreliable as google!
M.
My time for tears will be at my Victory...not at the start of the War. ~~Vickie

Posts.Title: Microcalcifications

Posts.Content:
Popping in with some personal experience,...
Avoiding Dr. Google (ahem) is a good way to start. Golly, if most of us got on there and googled all our symptoms, we'd have everything in the book, and then some.
I know it's easier said than done, but I agree with the others, and I'd strongly encourage you to make the appointment now, call today, and schedule an appointment for immediately when your insurance kicks in. If you wait until it kicks in, it could be a while before you get an appointment.
Being pro-active by scheduling the appointment is a more effective tool than focusing on Mr. Google.
The Breast Health Center that I went to also posts signs everywhere that if you cannot afford screening, they will provide it for you. There's no reason to wait out of fear. There are many Centers like this around the country, especially pertaining to a disease as high profile as BC.
Good luck to you, and get on the phone my dear, make that call, and book yourself that appointment! You'll be happy you did!
M.

I really did think that because it's soft tissue, that I wouldn't be hurting like this. The impression they gave me is that it isn't uncommon for women to only need half a vicodin. I relayed the meds I currently take, and that perhaps that is why the vicodin, for me, is not quite as effective.
She (surgeon's nurse) is phoning me again today for an update. She said there really isn't too much else they can give me for pain and I may have to rely on ice and wait it out for a few days.
The ice definitely helps. 
When I walk, especially down the steps, even in this bra (Jobe Bra?) I can feel pulling deep inside. So I walk and hold my breasts at the same time (not really the best idea given my balance isn't too good).
I have the idea that getting a new Rx, on a Friday, when I'm seeing him on Tuesday, especially for a pain med (given most cannot be phoned in),....well, it's probably not going to happen.
I have the one incision on the left one, and two on the right one, so most of my pain is between the nipple and arm pit on the right. 
I am so tired, just so very tired. I don't know how much is "real" or not (regarding what I perceive as "pulling" when I raise my arms or extend them out to the side)...
I've had multiple orthopedic problems and surgeries, so I guess a part of me is making comparisons. This isn't quite what I anticipated.
Fingers crossed for the path report... Thanks guys, all of you! You're my Support Team, especially in a scary and new journey!
M.

Just got a call from my surgeon's RN.
1) He approved giving me a few days of pain medicine, which I can pick up tomorrow. And that's fine because, as luck would have it (staying traditional to New England), we are being hit with another snow storm right now, and it's much too dangerous for me to go out.
2) I got the path report! NEGATIVE lymph nodes, clean margins, isolated to the tumor. Other tissues came back clean.
3) I see my surgeon Monday at which point I'll meet with one of the oncologists, and we discuss my plan for radiation therapy, as well as the potential of hormone therapy afterwards. (For good measure).
She said, now if we can just manage this pain situation, we'll be all set,...this is very good news!
I agree. I told her after all my orthopedic surgeries, I thought soft tissue surgery would be a cake walk and had no concerns (or very few, let's say) going in, re: my "ability" to handle it. I guess God's just throwing me a curve ball so that I'll remember to be thankful for what I do have (and, for what I do not).
I'll keep posting as things keep going on, and thank you HW for the prayers (see? see? HW has a direct line to the Man Upstairs, I just know it!)
Breathing a big sigh of relief.....

Posts.Title: ROLL CALL name, age, state and any other info to share

Age.Phrase: through the years  and I'm 51 so there's a lot of

PatientDecided.Sample: I was diagnosed with BC in November and had surgery in December. I elected to have the affected breast tissue removed at the same time....Because this is nuts. I'm expecting him to tell me it "shouldn't be hurting" like this a week after surgery....Mind you, I had surgery done on both breasts. BC was on the right, but I had what was considered prophylactic elective surgery where I choose to have tissue removed from both breasts that, while not cancerous, presented with significant changes from previous scans....If it were me, especially with your family history, I would be extremely pro-active and get the surgery to remove any questionable tissue. When I had my tumor removed, I also had elected to prophylactically remove any precancerous tissues that were showing changes from previous mammograms....Then as I slipped, I landed directly on my sacrum. When I had my back surgery (a year ago) he told me my L5-S1 was very tenuous, and he contemplated fusing that area as well because it was so damaged, but he decided against it to help keep me as mobile as possible....When I had my back surgery (a year ago) he told me my L5-S1 was very tenuous, and he contemplated fusing that area as well because it was so damaged, but he decided against it to help keep me as mobile as possible. So when he asked me if I was having back pain,...or back and leg pain,...and I told him both,-- things got silent for a bit....BC was on the right, but I had what was considered prophylactic elective surgery where I choose to have tissue removed from both breasts that, while not cancerous, presented with significant changes from previous scans. I wasn't taking any chances....But I'm 3 months to the year before my actual surgery, and 5 months since I finished radiation. I still have to use a numbing cream on my breast because of friction burns....
